heading.title: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]
[DCA s 149] s 149 Costs where no jurisdiction

p.text: Where any proceedings purport to be commenced in the Court and the Court has no jurisdiction to hear and dispose of the proceedings, the Court may, notwithstanding the lack of jurisdiction, make such order (if any) as it thinks fit for the payment by any party to any other party of the costs of the proceedings in the Court, and any such order for costs may be enforced as if the Court had had jurisdiction to hear and dispose of the proceedings.

In the absence of statutory provision, where a court had no jurisdiction it had no power to award costs: Ex parte Lawry (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) 183 ; Ex parte Charlton (1869) 8 SCR (NSW) 158 . See also Spath v Builders' Licensing Board (1974) 3 DCR 231 at 243 so far as the special jurisdiction is concerned. Specific costs provisions are set out in UCPR Pt 42.
The Governor may make regulations for or with respect to fees to be paid in respect of the business of the Court.
Regulations may be made under this section so as to apply differently according to such factors as may be specified in the regulations.
[subs (2) subst Act 1 of 1975 s 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 151] s 151 Fees form part of Consolidated Fund

leg:heading.title: Fees form part of Consolidated Fund

p.text: All fees received by a registrar under this Act shall be paid by the registrar to the Treasurer for payment to the Consolidated Fund.
[s 151 am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 8 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
An amount which:
was paid to a registrar for or on account of or for the use or benefit of any party to any proceedings, and
remains unclaimed in the hands of the registrar for one year after a party to the proceedings becomes entitled to claim the amount,
shall be paid by the registrar to the Treasurer and placed to the credit of the Special Deposits Account in the Treasury.

The provisions of section 14(3) and (4) of the Public Finance and Audit Act, 1983, apply to an amount placed to the credit of the Special Deposits Account under subsection (1) in the same way as they apply to money paid into that Account pursuant to section 14(2) of that Act.
[subs (2) subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 8]
All proceedings for offences against this Act shall be disposed of summarily before the Local Court.
[subs (1) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 7 ; Act 121 of 2001 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 7 July 2003 ; Act 94 of 2007 s 4 and Sch 2, effective 6 July 2009]
[subs (2) rep Act No 28 of 2005 Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005]

Where a person convicted of an offence against this Act is a corporation, every person who at the time of the commission of the offence was an officer of the corporation shall be deemed to have committed the like offence and be liable to the penalty provided by this Act for the offence accordingly, if the person knowingly and wilfully authorised or permitted the commission of the offence.
[s 154 am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 155] s 155 Civil remedy not affected by proceedings for an offence

leg:heading.title: Civil remedy not affected by proceedings for an offence

p.text: Notwithstanding any proceedings against a person for an offence against this Act (whether resulting in a conviction or otherwise) that person shall remain liable to all civil proceedings in like manner as if the proceedings for the offence had not been taken.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 156] s 156 General power of Court to stay proceedings

leg:heading.title: General power of Court to stay proceedings

p.text: At any stage of any proceedings, the Court may, on terms, order that the proceedings be stayed.
Nothing in subsection (1) limits any power conferred on the Court or a Judge by any other provision of this Act or by any other Act or rule of law to stay proceedings.
[s 156 subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 156.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 67.

Prior to the introduction of the Judicature Act of 1873 actions could only be stayed by injunction. Such an injunction could be issued by a superior court to prevent litigation which was considered either unnecessary in the sense of being vexatious or otherwise ill adapted to secure complete justice between the parties: Carron Iron Co v MacLaren (1885) 5 HL Cas 416; 10 ER 961. Section 24(5) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act 1873, which is the precursor of the present section, abolished the power to restrain proceedings by an injunction but expressly provided that it did not prevent the court from staying any proceedings “if it shall think fit”: see generally MacShannon v Rockware Glass Ltd [1978] AC 795; [1978] 1 All ER 625 . Although a properly instituted and bona fide action should normally be allowed to a hearing in the ordinary way: Cox v Journeaux (No 2) (1935) 52 CLR 713; 9 ALJR 127 ; Djordjevic v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (1964) 82 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 218 ; the court may stay proceedings whenever the interests of justice require: Tringali v Stewardson Stubbs & Collett Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 354; (1966) 66 SR (NSW) 335 at 344 (issue estoppel); Ferris v Lambton (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 56 at 57 ; Medaris v Lars Halvorsen & Sons Pty Ltd (1943) 44 SR (NSW) 71 at 76 ; Metropolitan Bank Ltd v Pooley (1885) 10 App Cas 210 at 220–1; [1881–5] All ER Rep 949; Mills v Cooper [1967] 2 QB 459 at 467; [1967] 2 All ER 100 ; Watson v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 685; 28 A Crim R 332 (stay of criminal proceedings).
There are numerous examples of instances where the power to stay may be appropriately exercised – see the notes to CPA s 67 .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 156.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 142, ss 67.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 12.10, 12.4, 51.44.

The court has power to order a stay under ss 67 and 142 of the CPA (stay pending application for transfer to a higher court). See notes to CPA s 67 as applicable to the District Court. See also the following provisions:
UCPR 12.4 Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of discontinued proceedings
UCPR 12.10 Stay of further proceedings to secure costs of proceedings dismissed
UCPR 51.44 Appeal proceedings do not operate as stay unless Court or court below directs

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 156.12] Stay – implied or incidental power to stay proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 156.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 [s 67.20].

heading.title: Stay – implied or incidental power to stay proceedings

p.text: The District Court is an inferior court of record and therefore does not have the inherent jurisdiction derived from the royal courts of justice: Irving v Askew (1870) LR 5 QB 208; R v Hackett; Ex parte Cline (1882) 8 VLR (L) 129 ; Levoune v Bacoulis 1935 AR (NSW) 126. However, any court endowed with a particular jurisdiction has all the powers necessary to enable it to act effectively within its jurisdiction and to control its own process and proceedings: Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254 at 1301; [1964] 2 All ER 401; (1964) 128 JP 418; [1964] 2 WLR 1145 ; Watson v A-G (NSW) (1987) 8 NSWLR 685; 28 A Crim R 332 (stay of criminal proceedings); John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Police Tribunal of New South Wales (1986) 5 NSWLR 465 at 476 . That power includes the ability to prevent its process being abused or vexatious or frivolous proceedings being continued in the court and it may operate to permit the court to restrain parties to proceedings before it from continuing oppressive or vexatious proceedings in another jurisdiction: see also CPA [s 67.20] .
See CPA [s 67.60] .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 156.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 51.44.
See UCPR 51.44 and the annotations thereto.

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 156.25] Concurrent civil and criminal proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 156.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Copyright Act 1968 [s 67.25].
See CPA [s 67.25] .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 156.30] Concurrent proceedings — restraining parties from prosecuting other proceedings

heading.title: Concurrent proceedings — restraining parties from prosecuting other proceedings

p.text: Although the present section only empowers the District Court to stay proceedings which are pending in the court, problems may sometimes arise where one of the parties to those proceedings has commenced proceedings against the other party in another jurisdiction. The question then arises as to whether either set of proceedings is oppressive and, if so, whether the court may restrain the plaintiff in the other proceedings from continuing with them using its implied powers: see [DCA s 156.12] . In answering the latter question, it is necessary to consider the nature of the power which is involved in the making of such a restraining order and in particular whether it is part of the inherent or implied powers of the court. See CPA [s 67.60] and [s 67.70] for discussion of implied powers to restrain a party from maintaining proceedings in another forum.
See CPA [s 67.35] and [s 67.40] .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 156.40] Forum non conveniens — stay of proceedings in the court

heading.title: Forum non conveniens — stay of proceedings in the court

p.text: See CPA [s 67.50] and [s 67.55] .
See CPA [s 67.65] .
See CPA [s 67.30] .
[s 157 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3 now see Pt 8 r 9]
[s 158 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3 now see Pt 1 r 5A]
[s 159 rep Act No 28 of 2005 Sch 5, effective 15 August 2005]
[s 160 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 3]
Note: see s 63 CPA.
